Check: External recipient/guest has access to sensitive mailbox items or shared mailboxes.
Business-Friendly Description: Non-employees can read internal email content or attachments. If their account is compromised—or they leave their company—confidential communications and PII can be exfiltrated, enabling phishing, legal exposure, or insider trading concerns.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: File system broad access to hidden/admin shares
Business-Friendly Description: Administrative shares (e.g., C$, ADMIN$) and hidden shares should be tightly controlled. If exploited, attackers sweep systems, deploy tools, and exfiltrate data over SMB.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File system broken inheritance with excessive explicit aces
Business-Friendly Description: Too many explicit permissions make ACLs complex and error‑prone. If exploited, attackers find overlooked grants to reach sensitive data unnoticed.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File system change permissions/take ownership to non-admins
Business-Friendly Description: Granting change‑permissions/ownership to non‑admins lets users rewrite access controls. If exploited, attackers elevate their own access and lock out legitimate owners.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File system excessive acl entries (acl bloat)
Business-Friendly Description: Bloated ACLs are difficult to review and easy to misconfigure. If exploited, attackers find gaps to escalate access or hide persistence via permissions.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File system local accounts on in acls
Business-Friendly Description: Local machine accounts in ACLs are hard to track across servers. If exploited, attackers compromise one server and gain access to files elsewhere via those local identities.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File System missing full control ACE
Business-Friendly Description: Some folders are missing a Full Control access control entry (ACE) for trusted administrators (e.g., BUILTIN\Administrators or NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM). Without that safety net, IT may be unable to reliably change permissions, evict bad entries, or recover ownership during incidents, backups, or migrations. If exploited, an attacker who gains write access can lock out admins by adding Deny ACEs, disable inheritance, replace the owner, and hide malicious files—turning routine remediation into an outage that may require offline recovery or restores. The result can be prolonged downtime, data loss, blocked investigations, and higher impact from ransomware or insider abuse.

Check: File system orphaned sids in acls
Business-Friendly Description: Orphaned SIDs represent unknown or deleted accounts that still hold rights. If exploited, attackers can recreate those SIDs or confuse reviews to keep illicit access.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File system over-nested groups creating implicit access
Business-Friendly Description: Deep group nesting hides who truly has file access. If exploited, attackers gain data access through indirect group paths that audits miss.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File system stale privileged access
Business-Friendly Description: Old grants linger after roles change, expanding the attack surface. If exploited, attackers use forgotten rights to read or alter sensitive data.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: File system unintended inheritance to sensitive paths
Business-Friendly Description: Some folders automatically inherit permissions from parent folders, unintentionally granting access to sensitive data. If exploited, an attacker who gains access to a parent location can inherit read/modify rights to confidential files, enabling silent data theft or tampering.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Anonymous sharing links are enabled (scope == anonymous).
Business-Friendly Description: Share links don’t require authentication across SharePoint/OneDrive. Anyone who gets the URL (even unintentionally) can access the file. If exposed (e.g., pasted into a ticket or chat), data can spread publicly and evade access logs, creating regulatory and reputational risk.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Guest user has access to sensitive content.
Business-Friendly Description: A partner/contractor account can view internal confidential data. If that guest account is hijacked or misused, information can be copied externally, harming competitive position and triggering contractual or regulatory issues.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Non-expiring (permanent) links are allowed.
Business-Friendly Description: Share links never expire. Old links continue to work long after the business need ends. If they surface in email threads, tickets, or web caches, outsiders may gain indefinite access to sensitive files.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Orphaned users (not resolvable in directory) still appear on ACLs.
Business-Friendly Description: Permissions reference accounts that no longer exist (or can’t be resolved). This breaks accountability and reviews. If an identity is later re-created or mapped, it may inherit unintended access; audits also fail due to unverifiable access lists.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Sharepoint 'everyone except external users' on sensitive libraries
Business-Friendly Description: This broad group grants access to nearly all employees. If exploited, sensitive data spreads internally and is easier to exfiltrate by any compromised user.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Sharepoint anyone links with edit
Business-Friendly Description: Anonymous edit links let unauthenticated users change files. If exploited, attackers deface content, insert malware, or corrupt records.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-6

Check: Sharepoint external sharing to consumer domains
Business-Friendly Description: Sharing to personal email domains weakens identity assurance and revocation. If exploited, attackers forward or retain access beyond business need.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-6

Check: Sharepoint guest accounts as site owners / full control
Business-Friendly Description: Guests with owner/full control bypass internal governance. If exploited, external users change permissions, exfiltrate data, or delete evidence.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-6

Check: Sharepoint open access (anyone links present)
Business-Friendly Description: ‘Anyone’ links allow anonymous access from the internet. If exploited, sensitive documents leak publicly and can be indexed by search engines.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-6

Check: Sharepoint sensitive data with visitors group misconfigured for edit
Business-Friendly Description: Visitors should be read‑only; granting edit to visitors broadens write access. If exploited, attackers alter or plant malicious files and mislead users.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Anonymous sharing links are enabled (scope == anonymous).
Business-Friendly Description: Share links don’t require authentication across SharePoint/OneDrive. Anyone who gets the URL (even unintentionally) can access the file. If exposed (e.g., pasted into a ticket or chat), data can spread publicly and evade access logs, creating regulatory and reputational risk.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Broken permission inheritance
Business-Friendly Description: A site/library/folder stopped inheriting permissions and has custom access that’s hard to see or review. Over time, this drifts into overexposure. If exploited, unauthorized users can read/alter/delete sensitive files, causing outages, data loss, or breaches.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Guest user has access to sensitive content.
Business-Friendly Description: A partner/contractor account can view internal confidential data. If that guest account is hijacked or misused, information can be copied externally, harming competitive position and triggering contractual or regulatory issues.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Non-expiring (permanent) links are allowed.
Business-Friendly Description: Share links never expire. Old links continue to work long after the business need ends. If they surface in email threads, tickets, or web caches, outsiders may gain indefinite access to sensitive files.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Orphaned users (not resolvable in directory) still appear on ACLs.
Business-Friendly Description: Permissions reference accounts that no longer exist (or can’t be resolved). This breaks accountability and reviews. If an identity is later re-created or mapped, it may inherit unintended access; audits also fail due to unverifiable access lists.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: File Shared with Everyone
Business-Friendly Description: A file or folder is open to all employees by default (“Everyone”/“Everyone except external users”). This breaks least-privilege. If abused, sensitive data can be harvested at scale by any compromised internal account.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Inactive user (>90 days) still retains permissions to SharePoint Online resources.
Business-Friendly Description: A dormant account still has SharePoint access. If abused, broad site content can be copied or tampered with, complicating forensics and recovery.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Anonymous links to files shared via Teams (backed by SharePoint/OneDrive) are enabled (scope == anonymous).
Business-Friendly Description: Files shared in Teams can be opened by anyone with the link—no sign-in required. If that link is forwarded or leaked, outsiders can read or download sensitive content without leaving a trace, leading to data leaks, loss of IP, and potential compliance fines.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Guest user has access to sensitive content.
Business-Friendly Description: A partner/contractor account can view internal confidential data. If that guest account is hijacked or misused, information can be copied externally, harming competitive position and triggering contractual or regulatory issues.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Org-wide Teams sharing  (scope == organization)
Business-Friendly Description: Teams channels or files are visible to everyone in the company by default. This increases insider risk and accidental exposure of HR, finance, or legal content, and makes it easier for attackers with any compromised account to find crown-jewel data.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Inactive user (>90 days) still retains permissions to Microsoft Teams resources.
Business-Friendly Description: A stale account still sees Teams chats/files. Compromise exposes conversations, shared docs, and links, enabling lateral movement and reputational harm if sensitive discussions leak.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: File System Empty Shares
Business-Friendly Description: Unused shares increase attack surface and confusion. If exploited, attackers stage tools or data exfiltration paths that go unnoticed.

Check: Site/workload is stale (no activity >180 days).
Business-Friendly Description: Old sites/teams linger without owners or reviews. They quietly accumulate risky links and guests. If exploited, they become easy backdoors for data theft and malware staging, and they complicate compliance and cleanup.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Sharepoint anyone links without expiration
Business-Friendly Description: Non‑expiring public links remain open indefinitely. If exploited, long‑forgotten links enable ongoing data leakage.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-6

Check: Sharepoint excessive unique permissions (broken inheritance sprawl)
Business-Friendly Description: Too many unique permissions create chaos and blind spots. If exploited, attackers hide access in one-off ACLs that reviews miss.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: Sharepoint files unresolved owner
Business-Friendly Description: Orphaned files lack stewardship and review. If exploited, attackers alter or exfiltrate data while oversight is missing.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: Sharepoint missing site owners (orphaned site)
Business-Friendly Description: Sites without owners lack stewardship and review. If exploited, attackers quietly accumulate access and manipulate content without accountability.
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-6

Check: Site/workload is stale (no activity >180 days).
Business-Friendly Description: Old sites/teams linger without owners or reviews. They quietly accumulate risky links and guests. If exploited, they become easy backdoors for data theft and malware staging, and they complicate compliance and cleanup.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Sensitive data (emails/attachments) shared externally across multiple domains.
Business-Friendly Description: Regulated or confidential email content is spread to many third-party domains. The wider the spread, the harder revocation and tracking become—raising breach impact, notification obligations, and legal exposure.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: File system sensitive data at share root with modify rights
Business-Friendly Description: Placing sensitive data at share roots with modify permissions increases accidental and malicious changes. If exploited, attackers overwrite or encrypt data at scale (ransomware).
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Files are stale (no access >365 days).
Business-Friendly Description: Old files linger but still carry sensitive data. They’re rarely reviewed, yet remain accessible. If compromised, attackers can mine years of unneeded data, increasing breach scope, incident costs, and discovery/sanctions risk.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Sensitive files shared to multiple external domains.
Business-Friendly Description: Files are shared with many outside organizations. Each domain adds risk—harder to control copies, increased chance of leaks, and complex incident response if data turns up elsewhere.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Onedrive sensitive data in personal employee drives
Business-Friendly Description: Personal OneDrives often bypass team controls. If exploited, attackers in a user account can access and share sensitive data outside approved channels.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-20, AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Sharepoint sensitive data + anyone link
Business-Friendly Description: Combining sensitive content with public links multiplies exposure. If exploited, widespread, hard‑to‑trace data leaks occur rapidly.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Sharepoint sensitive data accessible to 'everyone except external users'
Business-Friendly Description: Sensitive documents should never be broadly exposed. If exploited, any phished or malicious insider can mass-download data.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-14, AC-2, AC-20, AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Sharepoint sensitive data in communication sites with anonymous links
Business-Friendly Description: Communication sites are often internet-facing; anonymous links add risk. If exploited, external actors retrieve confidential files without authentication.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Files are stale (no access >365 days).
Business-Friendly Description: Old files linger but still carry sensitive data. They’re rarely reviewed, yet remain accessible. If compromised, attackers can mine years of unneeded data, increasing breach scope, incident costs, and discovery/sanctions risk.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Sensitive files shared to multiple external domains.
Business-Friendly Description: Files are shared with many outside organizations. Each domain adds risk—harder to control copies, increased chance of leaks, and complex incident response if data turns up elsewhere.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Sensitive files shared to multiple external domains.
Business-Friendly Description: Files are shared with many outside organizations. Each domain adds risk—harder to control copies, increased chance of leaks, and complex incident response if data turns up elsewhere.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Shared Channels with sensitive content
Business-Friendly Description: Teams Shared Channels can include external organizations. A misstep in membership or classification exposes high-value content across tenants; if exploited, competitors or threat actors gain ongoing access to conversations and files.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: File system sensitive data unencrypted at rest
Business-Friendly Description: Critical files stored without encryption are readable if storage is compromised. If exploited, attackers exfiltrate high‑value data with minimal effort and little trace.
GDPR: Art. 32 (security of processing); Art. 25 (privacy by design); Art. 5(1)(f) (integrity/confidentiality)
GLBA: Access controls (16 CFR Part 314); Encryption of customer information (Safeguards Rule)
ISO 27001: Annex A: Access control; Annex A: Information classification & handling; Annex A: Cryptography / protection of information at rest
PCI DSS: Req. 7 (restrict access by need-to-know); Req. 3 (protect stored account data)
SOX: ITGC: Access to programs and data
ASD ISM: Access control; Cryptographic protections (data at rest)
CJISSP: Access control (CJIS Security Policy); Encryption of CJI at rest
FISMA NIST: Aligns with NIST SP 800-53: AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, SC-28

Check: Accounts with adminCount=1 but not currently in privileged groups
Business-Friendly Description: AdminSDHolder ‘lingering’ flags mean an account retains protected ACLs even after leaving admin groups. If exploited, attackers leverage these protections to resist remediation or keep hidden backdoors.

Check: Admin accounts not in Protected Users group
Business-Friendly Description: Protected Users enhances safeguards (no NTLM, no cached creds, limited delegation). If exploited, absence of these controls makes admin credentials easier to steal and reuse.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Admin accounts with SPN configured
Business-Friendly Description: Admin SPNs expose high‑value tickets to Kerberoasting. If exploited, cracked hashes yield administrator passwords and immediate escalation.

Check: Admin accounts with unprivileged owners
Business-Friendly Description: If non‑admins own admin accounts/objects, they can silently change permissions. If exploited, attackers maintain hidden control and undo security fixes.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Admin accounts without adminCount=1
Business-Friendly Description: Privileged accounts should inherit AdminSDHolder protections. If exploited, missing protections allow permission drift or malicious ACL changes on admin principals.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Clear Text Password
Business-Friendly Description: Passwords stored or transmitted in clear text are immediately readable. If exploited, attackers log in directly, impersonate users, and exfiltrate data without cracking.

Check: Constrained delegation with protocol transition (TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION)
Business-Friendly Description: Protocol transition allows a service to obtain Kerberos tickets without the user’s original TGT. If exploited, attackers misuse the service to impersonate users to back-end systems, including admins.

Check: Contractor accounts (employeeType=Contractor) without 'accountExpires'
Business-Friendly Description: Contractor accounts without an expiry date can outlive their business need. If exploited, former contractors (or attackers using their credentials) can continue logging in and accessing internal systems indefinitely.

Check: DES Encryption Only
Business-Friendly Description: DES is obsolete and weak for Kerberos encryption. If exploited, attackers forge or crack tickets far faster, enabling impersonation and domain traversal.

Check: Disabled accounts still members of groups
Business-Friendly Description: Disabled users that remain in groups keep latent privileges that can reappear if the account is re-enabled or duplicated. If exploited, reactivation or cloning restores powerful access immediately, enabling privilege escalation without going through approvals.

Check: Disabled admin accounts present
Business-Friendly Description: Disabled admin accounts clutter directories and may be re‑enabled by mistake. If exploited, reactivation restores powerful access without scrutiny.

Check: Disabled members in sensitive groups
Business-Friendly Description: Disabled users left in admin groups retain latent privilege links. If exploited, re‑enablement or SID reuse instantly grants elevated access.

Check: Domain password policy too weak (length/history/lockout/complexity)
Business-Friendly Description: Weak password rules make credentials easy to guess or crack. If exploited, attackers gain initial footholds quickly and pivot using reused or predictable passwords.

Check: Enabled user accounts stale (no recent lastLogonTimestamp)
Business-Friendly Description: Enabled accounts that haven’t logged in recently are often forgotten and unmonitored. If exploited, attackers can take over these dormant accounts to bypass detection and move laterally with valid credentials.

Check: External/forest trusts without SID filtering (SIDHistory allowed)
Business-Friendly Description: Trusts that accept SIDHistory can be abused to inject extra privileges across forests. If exploited, attackers forge SIDs to gain admin rights in the trusting domain.

Check: Foreign Security Principals in admin groups
Business-Friendly Description: External identities in admin groups rely on trust configurations you might not control. If exploited, attackers from partner/child forests can administer your environment.

Check: Guest account enabled
Business-Friendly Description: The built‑in Guest account bypasses normal onboarding and auditing. If exploited, anonymous or shared access can modify data and mask who did it.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Indirect privileged access via nested groups
Business-Friendly Description: Nested groups can hide who truly has admin rights. If exploited, attackers slip into privilege through a lower‑level group and gain powerful access that escapes simple reviews.

Check: Kerberos krbtgt account with old password
Business-Friendly Description: Old krbtgt keys allow long‑lived ticket forgery. If exploited, attackers mint ‘Golden Tickets’ to persist with near‑invisibility.

Check: Krbtgt account with Resource-Based Constrained Delegation
Business-Friendly Description: Delegation settings touching krbtgt/DCs are extremely risky. If exploited, attackers impersonate users to core services and compromise the domain.

Check: krbtgt password age exceeds threshold
Business-Friendly Description: The krbtgt account keys sign Kerberos tickets across the domain; they must be rotated regularly. If exploited, stolen keys allow ‘Golden Ticket’ creation, granting unlimited, stealthy domain access.

Check: LM Hash
Business-Friendly Description: LM hashes are trivial to crack with modern hardware. If exploited, attackers quickly recover passwords and reuse them across systems.

Check: MachineAccountQuota allows non‑admins to join computers (ms-DS-MachineAccountQuota > 0)
Business-Friendly Description: Allowing standard users to add machines to the domain can be abused to register rogue computers. If exploited, attackers create controlled hosts to request tickets and move laterally.

Check: Non-admins in DNS Admins group
Business-Friendly Description: DNSAdmins can load code into the DNS service on DCs, effectively becoming Domain Admin. If exploited, attackers execute arbitrary code and seize domain control.

Check: Objects created in past 7 days
Business-Friendly Description: A surge in new objects (users/computers) can signal staging or misconfiguration. If exploited, attackers hide backdoor accounts among legitimate changes and return later.

Check: Objects with Constrained Delegation
Business-Friendly Description: Delegation permits services to act on users’ behalf to specific targets. If exploited, attackers pivot through those services to impersonate users and reach sensitive systems.

Check: Old password (>180 days) in Sensitive Security Groups
Business-Friendly Description: Aged privileged passwords increase exposure and reuse risk. If exploited, attackers leverage unchanged secrets to operate as admins.

Check: Oldest password in sensitive groups
Business-Friendly Description: Tracking the oldest privileged password highlights worst‑case risk. If exploited, that one weak link can enable wide‑reaching compromise.

Check: Password expired
Business-Friendly Description: Expired passwords indicate lifecycle issues and potential account neglect. If exploited (e.g., via reset processes), attackers may socially engineer resets to take control.

Check: Password never expires
Business-Friendly Description: Perpetual passwords accumulate exposure and reuse. If exploited, attackers keep access for long periods without triggering rotations.

Check: Password not required
Business-Friendly Description: Accounts allowed without passwords remove core authentication. If exploited, unauthorized users authenticate instantly as the account.

Check: Password not required in sensitive groups
Business-Friendly Description: Admin accounts without required passwords are catastrophic. If exploited, attackers gain domain‑level access with no barrier.

Check: Passwords older than a year
Business-Friendly Description: Very old passwords are likely known or reused. If exploited, attackers authenticate freely and blend in using valid credentials.

Check: Passwords stored with reversible encryption
Business-Friendly Description: Reversible storage means passwords can be recovered from directory data. If exploited, attackers steal cleartext credentials and reuse them widely.

Check: Pre-Windows 2000 Compatible Access group members
Business-Friendly Description: This legacy group broadens read access for backward compatibility. If exploited, attackers enumerate sensitive objects and plan targeted attacks.

Check: Privileged accounts with 'Password never expires' set
Business-Friendly Description: Non‑expiring admin passwords are high‑value, long‑lived targets. If exploited, attackers retain persistent, privileged access that evades normal password‑rotation defenses.

Check: Privileged accounts with SIDHistory present
Business-Friendly Description: SIDHistory preserves legacy privileges that may exceed current roles. If exploited, attackers replay historical SIDs to regain high-level access and evade least‑privilege controls.

Check: Privileged accounts without 'Smartcard required'
Business-Friendly Description: Admins without strong MFA are vulnerable to phishing and credential replay. If exploited, attackers use stolen passwords or hashes to operate with admin rights, deploy malware, or exfiltrate data.

Check: Privileged group membership too broad (e.g., Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins)
Business-Friendly Description: Too many admins creates unnecessary blast radius and review burden. If exploited, compromise of any one admin yields full control, increasing the chance and impact of domain breach.

Check: Privileged groups missing 'managedBy' owner
Business-Friendly Description: Without an accountable owner, privileged groups drift and accumulate excess members. If exploited, over‑permissioned groups enable quick escalation and make cleanup slow and error‑prone.

Check: Privileged groups with foreign members (ForeignSecurityPrincipals)
Business-Friendly Description: Foreign members grant external identities admin access via trusts. If exploited, attackers from another forest/domain can administer your environment or bypass local controls.

Check: Privileged user accounts with Service Principal Names (SPNs) set
Business-Friendly Description: Admin users with SPNs are prime Kerberoast targets. If exploited, cracked tickets yield admin passwords, enabling rapid domain‑wide compromise.

Check: Recent logon by BUILTIN\Administrator
Business-Friendly Description: Use of the built‑in Administrator signals backdoor or unsafe practices. If exploited, attackers operate under a well‑known, powerful identity that’s hard to trace to a person.

Check: Recently created admins
Business-Friendly Description: New admin accounts require heightened scrutiny and approvals. If exploited, attackers create stealthy admins and retain access even after cleanup.

Check: Resource-Based Constrained Delegation on a computer
Business-Friendly Description: RBCD lets a computer designate who can act for it. If exploited, attackers impersonate users to that host’s services and escalate.

Check: Resource‑based constrained delegation (RBCD) grants to low‑priv principals
Business-Friendly Description: RBCD allows a resource to specify who can act on its behalf; granting this to low-priv objects is dangerous. If exploited, attackers abuse RBCD to impersonate users to that resource and escalate.

Check: Risky constrained delegation targets (msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo includes DC services)
Business-Friendly Description: Delegation to domain controller services (like CIFS/LDAP) is overly powerful. If exploited, attackers can impersonate admins directly to DCs, leading to domain takeover.

Check: Service accounts (SPN set) with 'Password never expires'
Business-Friendly Description: Non‑expiring service secrets accumulate exposure over time. If exploited, attackers keep reusing the same credential to access critical applications and data.

Check: Service accounts not marked 'Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated' (NOT_DELEGATED)
Business-Friendly Description: Sensitive service accounts should not be used for delegation. If exploited, attackers abuse delegation paths to impersonate users and expand access.

Check: Service Accounts trusted for delegation
Business-Friendly Description: Delegation‑trusted accounts can impersonate users to certain services. If exploited, attackers expand access paths and harvest sensitive data via impersonation.

Check: Service accounts with old 'pwdLastSet' (key age)
Business-Friendly Description: Aged service keys increase the chance they’ve leaked or been cracked. If exploited, attackers authenticate to services and pivot to databases, file shares, or code deployment systems.

Check: Service accounts with SPN but no AES keys configured
Business-Friendly Description: Service accounts lacking modern AES keys fall back to weaker crypto (e.g., RC4), easing Kerberoasting. If exploited, attackers crack service tickets offline and reuse the recovered password across systems.

Check: Unconstrained delegation enabled (TRUSTED_FOR_DELEGATION)
Business-Friendly Description: Unconstrained delegation lets a service impersonate users broadly. If exploited, attackers controlling that service can capture TGTs and act as high‑privilege users anywhere in the domain.

Check: UPN suffix outside approved domains
Business-Friendly Description: Unapproved UPN suffixes confuse identity checks and SSO routing. If exploited, attackers spoof identities or trick users into authenticating to look‑alike domains.

Check: User accounts with SPN configured
Business-Friendly Description: User SPNs expose tickets to Kerberoasting. If exploited, cracked hashes reveal the user’s password and any shared credentials.

Check: User SPNs on non‑service users (misuse of user accounts for services)
Business-Friendly Description: Running services as ordinary users creates risky SPNs tied to human credentials. If exploited, Kerberoasting or password reuse exposes both the service and the person’s other access.

Check: Users with 'Do not require Kerberos preauthentication' (DONT_REQUIRE_PREAUTH)
Business-Friendly Description: Skipping Kerberos preauthentication lets attackers request encrypted blobs that can be cracked offline. If exploited, it enables identity impersonation and further lateral movement using forged tickets.

Check: Users with 'Password never expires' (DONT_EXPIRE_PASSWORD)
Business-Friendly Description: Never-expiring passwords turn into long-lived secrets that inevitably leak. If exploited, an old credential remains valid for months or years, enabling recurring unauthorized access.

Check: Users with 'Password not required' (PASSWD_NOTREQD)
Business-Friendly Description: Accounts allowed to exist without a password eliminate a critical security barrier. If exploited, anyone can authenticate as that user, leading to immediate data exposure or privilege abuse.

Check: Users with reversible encryption allowed (ENCRYPTED_TEXT_PWD_ALLOWED)
Business-Friendly Description: Reversible passwords are effectively stored in a recoverable form. If exploited, attackers can reconstruct cleartext passwords and reuse them across systems, accelerating compromise.

Check: Users with Unconstrained Delegation
Business-Friendly Description: Unconstrained delegation on users lets them capture TGTs presented to their services. If exploited, attackers impersonate high‑value users broadly.

Check: Users without manager/ownership metadata (no 'manager' attribute) in privileged groups
Business-Friendly Description: Privileged users lacking a recorded manager/owner have weak accountability and unclear review responsibility. If exploited, risky access persists unnoticed, aiding insider threats and hampering incident response.

Check: Inactive external recipient/guest still has access to sensitive mailbox data.
Business-Friendly Description: A guest who no longer engages still retains mailbox access. Dormant accounts are easy targets; if breached, attackers quietly read sensitive mail, pivoting to fraud (e.g., invoice/CEO fraud) and brand damage.
MITRE ATT&CK: T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage), T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Services)

Check: Inactive user (>90 days) still retains permissions to Exchange resources.
Business-Friendly Description: Former or dormant internal accounts still have email access. If those credentials are leaked or guessed, attackers can read mail, reset passwords, or impersonate staff, driving BEC (business email compromise) and data theft.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2

Check: Inactive user (>90 days) still retains permissions to OneDrive resources.
Business-Friendly Description: Personal OneDrive data for an inactive user remains accessible. If taken over, attackers can harvest documents or use the account as a hidden exfiltration path.
NIST SP 800-53 (Rev.5): AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6, IA-2, IA-5, AU-2
